title: 107_s600
content: The text discusses an increase in penalties for violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act, with fines and imprisonment for different levels of violations. The amendment applies to violations occurring after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 2. STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS amended to extend from 3 to 5 years. Effective for violations after enactment. SEC. 3. SENTENCING GUIDELINES. The United States Sentencing Commission is required to create guidelines for penalties related to violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. These guidelines must reflect the seriousness of the violations and the need for strong law enforcement action. The guidelines for penalties related to violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 include sentencing enhancements for various types of violations, such as those involving foreign sources, large illegal transactions, governmental funds, and intent to benefit from the Government. Additionally, there are sentencing enhancements for violations by candidates or high-ranking campaign officials to ensure consistency with other relevant laws. The United States Sentencing Commission must create guidelines within 90 days of the enactment of the Act, ensuring consistency with other laws and considering circumstances that may warrant exceptions. The guidelines should align with the purposes of sentencing under section 3553(a)(2) of title 18, United States Code. The Commission must create guidelines within 90 days of enactment, following procedures from the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987. SEC. 4. PROHIBITION ON CONTRIBUTIONS AND DONATIONS BY FOREIGN NATIONALS. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 prohibits foreign nationals and domestic subsidiaries of foreign nationals from making contributions or donations in connection with elections or selecting candidates for political office. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 prohibits foreign nationals and domestic subsidiaries from making contributions or donations in connection with elections. An exception is made for domestic subsidiaries that can show they have sufficient funds in their own accounts. The term "donation" includes gifts, subscriptions, loans, advances, or deposits of money. The Federal Election Campaign Act prohibits foreign nationals and domestic subsidiaries from making contributions in connection with elections. The term "donation" includes gifts, subscriptions, loans, advances, or deposits of money to political committees or candidates. Amendment to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 changes the heading to "RESTRICTIONS ON FOREIGN NATIONALS." Amendment to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 prohibits donations in the name of another.
